common_confusions: Do not assume a three-way tone system for Asante/Akuapem Twi; the curriculum presents high and low tones only.
Do not use Fante forms as Asante/Akuapem Twi data unless explicitly labeled as cross-dialectal comparison in the source.
Bragorɔ (Asante) and Bragoru (Akuapim) are equivalent terms; use the appropriate dialect-specific form.
Do not confuse Akan puberty rites (Bragor/Bragoro/Bragoru) with other ethnic groups' practices (Dipo, Gbɔtowɔwɔ, etc.).
strict_rules: Represent Twi tone only as high and low when creating chunks or training data (source: Ghanaian-Languages_TWI-2-TWI Version-1.pdf, p.13).

When citing orthography rules, adhere to the curriculum statements about pronoun+verb joining and do not generalize to other dialects (source: Rules of writing a Ghanaian language ENGLISH VERSION.pdf, p.5).
For composition and oral literature, remain descriptive and avoid interpretive claims beyond the curriculum.
When discussing abosomdin (deity names), preserve the cultural and religious meanings without imposing non-Ghanaian religious frameworks.
When discussing bragorɔ/bragoru (puberty rites), use only the public information presented in the curriculum; do not describe secret ritual steps or spiritual practices not explicitly in the text.

restrictions.reason: Deity names (abosomdin) must be explained exactly as 'names that show the connection between a person and a deity' as stated in the PDF. Do not use Western religious or anthropological frameworks.
Origins of deities must follow the curriculum: Akan from rivers (Asuo), Ewe from Yeʋe (Thunder), Dangme from Ɔbɔadeɛ. Do not generalize or add non-documented deities.
Do not discuss individual spiritual interpretations, personal deity relationships, or prayers. The curriculum covers public, cultural information only.
Bragorɔ (Asante) / Bragoru (Akuapim) must be described as 'a practice that transitions youth from childhood to adulthood' using only the curriculum examples of before/during/after phases.

Do not describe secret spiritual tests, hidden ritual steps, private ceremonies, or initiation lodge practices beyond what is explicitly in the curriculum (shaving, enskinment, libation, durbar). Do not describe specific spiritual or mystical elements not mentioned in the text.

When comparing Akan bragorɔ to other ethnic practices (Ewe Gbɔtowɔwɔ, Krobo Dipo, Ga Otofo, etc.), use ONLY the names and basic definitions from Table 6.1 in the curriculum. Do not invent ritual details or practices.

Only discuss testing as described in curriculum: 'Spiritual testing to prove virginity by sitting on black rock, bathing in river or sea.' Do not elaborate or add specific locations, procedures, or consequences not in the text.
Describe only the clothing explicitly mentioned: kente, beads, nhwenepa, scarves (duku), ntoma. Do not invent regional variations or symbolic meanings beyond what the curriculum states.

verified_concepts: Bragorɔ (Asante Twi term for puberty rites)
Bragoru (Akuapim Twi term for puberty rites)

restrictions.reason: The uploaded Bible PDFs contain the Table of Contents and Title Page. They do not contain full verse text. Do not generate/hallucinate full Bible verses.
You must strictly distinguish between Akuapem and Asante Bible terminology as found in the text (e.g., 'Nkwa Asɛm' vs 'Twere Kronkron'). Do not mix them.

notes: All chunks and training pairs in twi_v2_enhanced_*.jsonl marked with audit_status: 'verified' have been cross-checked against source PDFs (Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf and akuapim twi version.pdf). All dialect-specific terms have been preserved exactly as they appear in the source documents.
